ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned signing vocab, grammatical structure, and Deaf culture.

I came in with no knowledge of ASL, but I am now able to hold a very basic conversation. Not only did I learn about the language, I learned about Deaf Culture and was able to interact with the Deaf community all throughout the semester.

I developed the skills of being able to hold my own in a conservation with another Deaf person. Of course there is so much more to learn, but for being the first class in the ASL program, you sure do learn a lot.

I developed the ability to communicate in another language, learn more about a new culture, and experience Deaf Culture. I also think I developed better spatial awareness and expression understanding skills.
Communication skills and the usage of facial expressions.
I felt that I was able to gain a great amount of knowledge in sign language in terms of the language itself and of deaf culture.
I learned how to read and sign ASL in very simple topics. I learned how to ask questions and communicate with someone who is deaf

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Every class was so engaging and I looked forward to getting to sign everyday. I enjoyed all of the assignments, activities, and the service project. The only improvement would be to mix up the seating arrangement more so that people have the opportunity to sign with new classmates and get used to different signing "accents".

love this course, finally got into it on my second go around of trying to after they added more sections. the only aspect of this class that could be improved is the community service project. there's little to no structure, and it is up to students to figure out how to go about it. it's also a big-time ask for community involvement hours distribution to give to students. Julia didn't monitor how many hours we specifically spent where which was nice because I never kept track, I just went to the events that I was available for. And that wasn't the majority of them, but still a good amount. 

ASL students and ASL users at Yale have such a cool integrated community that other language communities don't have. it's something really unique to the ASL community that I really love.

Strengths: Everything about the class, especially having Fridays be asynchronous days.

Weaknesses: This is not so much a weakness, as it is an understanding that this was a pilot program, but an improvement in clarity of how the service projects are supposed to function would be beneficial.

Strengths: Very engaging, taught in a clear manner, adapts to the day-the-day needs of students and encourages a learning environment. Professor is very nice. 

Weaknesses: Did not have a running list of signs learned throughout the semester. I think having this (even if its small) would help quantify progress.

I feel that this class had a teacher that took their time with students to make sure that they learned and were able to stay engaged during class time and also provided ample opportunity to learn outside of class time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this. The ASL dept is unlike any other language in terms of the commitment to community building. I really appreciate how welcoming people are of signers of all levels at various events.
Absolutely!!

yes, absolutely, 100%

ASL students and ASL users at Yale have such a cool integrated community that other language communities don't have. it's something really unique to the ASL community that I really love.
Yes absolutely! It's very engaging and a great way to learn more about the Deaf community!

Absolutely! This class will make you aware of Deaf culture, which is so fascinating! And, it will make you want to go all the way to L5 in ASL because of how supportive the ASL program. I believe the support found in the instruction of ASL at Yale is truly unparalleled in the other languages offered.

Yes, I highly recommend this class, regardless of your previous experience with Deaf Culture and ASL. Dr. Julia is a great professor to help facilitate learning and she is very encouraging and engaging every day. I think anyone would benefit from this class because you learn the foundations of ASL, learn more about a different culture, and have a ton of fun.
Yes, it teaches you so much and is a pleasure to be in class each day
I feel that I would definitely recommend this class to another student who is looking for an engaging language class.
Yes absolutely. You learn a lot about deaf culture and the professors really want to help you learn
